Posts.Content: Hi Clarkie 13 You’ve done the right thing telling your hubby and seeing the GP. I kept my lump to myself for a couple of weeks last October whilst I was trying to work out in my head if it felt the same the other side, was it my age (49), I wasn’t exactly sure what normal was meant to feel like. When I told my hubby, he insisted I made an appointment ASAP to get it checked out. The GP referred me to the breast clinic due to my age (lol), if I was 25 she to,d me she wouldn’t bother! My clinic appointment didn’t come through until December about 5 weeks later and then I had a mmamgram one week, ultrasound and biopsy the following week. Due to Christmas and new year it meant I didn’t get my results until early January.  I did have early stage breast cancer and it’s been an awful few months of tests waiting, more tests , more waiting not to mention the continuous worrying etc but these clinics are amazing. The staff are there to support you and it was stressed right from the beginning that breast cancer today is treatable and that they they would do their very best to take care of me which they have. Obviously some lumps turn out to be nothing but until it’s checked out you won’t get that peace of mind.  This forum has been a life saver for me to ask questions and also just read up on what others are going through, showing me I’m not alone and that others are far worse off than me. Whatever your results may be you will get through it so in the meantime take care and let us know how you get on. Sending hugs Helen xx
Posts.Title: New to the club

Posts.Content: Not sure if this is much help but my mum had very fine eyebrows which had became almost nonexistent as she got older so a couple of years ago she had them tattooed! They do look quite good to be honest. Have you looked at microblading? That’s quite a current procedure for a fuller eyebrows look - have seen pics and they look better than the tattooed ones. Not exactly sure of the process though Helen
Posts.Title: Eyrbrows still thin

Posts.Content: Hi I had an implant 8 weeks ago, it looks natural ie you can’t see the outline of the implant - I think it sits under some of my chest muscle at the top and then there’s a mesh covering the lower half. I didn’t ask many questions . On the day of my surgery consultant mentioned an expander implant but I felt it was too late in the day to be changing plans plus I just wanted it over and done with.  It obviously feels a bit weird but I kept my nipple so it still looks like a normal boob.  Recovery was fairly quick and my only concern is that it’s too small, at least a cup size smaller than my healthy breast so I’ve been wearing some inserts in my bra to fill it out - bought a pack of 12 from Amazon.  Good luck with your surgery Helen xx
Posts.Title: Advice please! Cannot decide between LD flap and implant or expanders...

Posts.Content: I’ll be interested to see what replies you get as my implant is quite a bit smaller than my real boob - bras are a nightmare! I did buy some pads to wear but find them quite uncomfortable to wear for long. Got my first anniversary appointment in the morning (been cancelled 3 times already) so will see what they say then. Helen x
Posts.Title: Lipomodelling is it worth it

Posts.Content: I was in exactly the same position as you and it’s so hard to decide what to do! The MDT decided that an Mx rather than a 3rd excision was the best option for me although if I insisted on a 3rd then they would go along with that. I opted for the mx with immediate reconstruction with implant as I wasn’t sure I could face a 3rd failed excision. In hindsight I wish I’d had another go. However I’ve just had my 1st anniversary check up and all is good. All the best with whatever you decide xx
Posts.Title: Mastectomy or re- excision?

Posts.Content: Hi all Well it was results day today, mixture of good and bad! Good news, no sign of invasive cells in lymph nodes but they didn’t get clear margins with the lumpectomy. Lumpectomy confirmed that it’s definitely DCIS  but it’s more widespread than they expected. Going back in next week to have further margins removed!  I know this sounds really vain but I’m so worried about how it’s going to look and they may still not get it all anyway!!!  Feeling angry with everyone at the moment
Posts.Title: Second surgery following lumpectomy and SNB

Posts.Content: Hi Jo  Had the results from my 2nd WLE yesterday - margins clear in 5 out of 6. They’ve given me the decision to make to either have a 3rd WLE or have a mastectomy with immediate reconstruction. My head is in a right spin, I know I may end up with the mastectomy anyway if the 3rd one doesn’t work! Boob looks ok at the mo - no different to the other one, just feels different!  I know it’s up to me but it helps talking to someone who’s actually been through the exact same thing! Thanks Helen x
Posts.Title: Second surgery following lumpectomy and SNB

Posts.Content: Thanks you so much for that, I’m glad to know I’m not the only one who’s had this dilemma. I think it is the sister thing that’s bothering me - not being identical twins. Have an appointment on Monday for a second opinion as everything has happened so quickly over the last couple of months we haven’t had time to think. I’ve gone from having a non suspicious 8mm lump to them wanting to take my boob off, all in the space of 7 weeks. I’m seeing my BCN next week as well and she’s going to go through the options and procedures with me, including pics. So I’ll have to decide after I’ve seen her as well. Xx
Posts.Title: Second surgery following lumpectomy and SNB

Posts.Content: Lennie01, I think at 49 many of us would like perkier ones , and that’s  what I’ve been thinking having something done to the other one as well so that they are more symmetrical if I end up down the mastectomy route!  I’ll see what the consultant says I’m seeing on Monday. This wasn’t how my 50th birthday year was meant to spent!  X
Posts.Title: Second surgery following lumpectomy and SNB

Posts.Content: Thanks everyone I have calmed down somewhat now! I know it’s just wait and see what happens again  Helen x
Posts.Title: Second surgery following lumpectomy and SNB

Posts.Content: Well that is one of my concerns, 1 perky twin and 1 49 year old droopy one! That did make me smile.  It’s finally started snowing here in South Wales, been waiting all day ❄️☃️ Xx
Posts.Title: Second surgery following lumpectomy and SNB

Posts.Content: Hi Kim That’s totally understandable, I think I can speak for everybody on here when I say we all felt exactly the same way when we had our diagnosis. Did you meet your BCN? They’re brilliant and can usually answer any questions you may have. It’s worth giving her a ring and maybe popping down for a chat! Have they given you any idea of a treatment plan? I know when I was told, they basically gave me my diagnosis then gave me a week for it to sink in before I went back and they told me what to expect. Everybody is different and everyone has different treatment plans. This forum is amazing for getting advice and support and I’m sure some of the more experienced ladies will post soon. Sending big hugs and take care Helen xx
Posts.Title: Stage 1 grade 3 , 7mm lump terrified :(

Posts.Content: Hi Kathryn My girls are 18 and 16 so it’s a summer of exams for us, A levels and GCSEs  I was more worried about how all this was going to affect them but they seem to be fine. I did inform the school and college just so they could keep an eye in case their work suffered. Been out walking a bit this week enjoying the sunshine and even ventured to the gym yesterday for half and hour with a friend. I only did some gentle leg work but can feel my legs aching a bit today! Hubby and I went out for a meal on our own last night which was lovely, 18 year old then picked us up so we could have a couple of glasses of wine. Another nice day here again today so another walk it is. Have a good weekend all  Helen xx
Posts.Title: mixed emotions

Posts.Content: Hi Kathryn I felt exactly the same as you pre op, esp No3 op. I didn’t want to socialise at all, I was happy just being with my family and a few select friends. 3 weeks post mx I am feeling much better, still not confident to socialise much but did pop out for a meal with hubby and the girls last weekend. I’ve been out for a few walks this week and went to the salon for a leg wax and went back again today for a facial so I’m getting there.  Results next week and hopefully can get on with getting some sort of normality back. It’s the waiting that’s the worst. My mx scar is healing really well and my new boob is looking good so please don’t spend the next 11 days worrying too much ( says she who was in pieces beforehand). You will feel so much better once it’s done. Take care Helen x
Posts.Title: mixed emotions

Posts.Content: Thinking of you today Kathryn b, hope all goes well. Sending positive thoughts and hugs. Helen x
Posts.Title: mixed emotions

Posts.Content: Hi moomy I will let you know how I get on, apparently the drains are the worst bit of the surgery so I’ve been told!  Also ordered a button up nightdress in case that’s easier. Have a few soft non wired bras from when I had my WLE’s so will take them in with me. Just spoken to my nurse and she said it’s usually a 2 night stay - am sure they’ll want me out of the way for Easter.  All the best for Tuesday  Helen xx
Posts.Title: masterctomy and reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi I’m actually going in next Wednesday for a mastectomy on my right breast with an immediate reconstruction using an implant! Hoping to keep my nipple, well i’ll have it for a little bit unless the biopsy comes back unfavourable then it will have to go.  It’s been a big decision for me to make but after 3 months of going back and for excisions, waiting for results and all the associated stress I think i’ll Be glad to get it done. My BCN showed me pics of the recons that my consultant had done and I was surprised at how good they were - in most cases it was hard to tell which was the reconstructed one. You are very young so imagine your boobs are in good condition anyway. I’m 49, and have had 2 children, breast fed both and apparently my boobs are in good shape taking all that into account lol!  Also saw a private plastic surgeon who showed me some of his pics and again the results are really very good. My surgeon is going to go in through the side and slightly under my breast (I’m a C cup).  I know i’ll have one slightly perkier than the other but I’ve been told that in the future I can have the other one lifted to match up if I’m that concerned.  One of the ladies on here told me that her surgeon told her they won’t exactly be twins but they will be sisters - that did make me smile. Not sure if this has been any help but I wish you all the best. Take care of yourself  Helen xx Ps my main concern is the lack of feeling which I think will be the hardest thing to get used too.
Posts.Title: masterctomy and reconstruction

Posts.Content: I’ve had 2 WLE for high grade DCIS, 1 margin left showing less than 1mm clearance. My surgeon says it has to be 1mm so has advised a further WLE or a mastectomy with immediate reconstruction using an implant. I’m still unsure which way to go - it’s been 3 weeks since my last surgery but I wanted some time to think. If clear after a 3rd WLE I will have 3 weeks radiotherapy but if I opt for the mastectomy then that’s it. I’m learning that nothing  is ever straightforward with this. Good luck  Helen x
Posts.Title: Narrow margin of clear tissue after a breast cancer lumpectomy.

Posts.Content: Hi Tulip16 I saw a plastic surgeon last night who also does mastectomies and recons for the nhs, he’s very much of the belief that if there’s a chance of keeping a breast then that’s the best option especially as I have DCIS which is non invasive and is only in the one area. Seeing my consultant tomorrow and going to ask for another WLE but maybe with guide wires to ensure they are in the right place as it’s just the one margin that’s not big enough. Will see what they say. All the best for your 2nd WLE, I think generally most people have success with their 2nd, I’m just awkward Helen x
Posts.Title: Narrow margin of clear tissue after a breast cancer lumpectomy.

Posts.Content: Hi Julie If you’re not bothered about it then I wouldn’t worry. I had my surgery at the end of March and now things have settled down my new boob is very much smaller than my normal one and I am really unhappy about the way I look now. I was 50 two weeks ago and really don’t want to have more surgery (I had 2 excisions before the mx) and I am so grateful and lucky the cancer has gone  but I also know I don’t want look like this so I’m going to have revision surgery as soon as I can. That is just how I feel but I know some women are quite happy not to have had reconstruction at all, so it’s all down to what you want and will be happy with. Helen x
Posts.Title: Breast reconstruction yes or no?

Posts.Content: Thanks Jo Jo that’s good to know xx
Posts.Title: Advice re drain fluid has become dark red last 36 hours

Posts.Content: Hi  I’m 10 days post mastectomy with implant and after having my dressings changed on thursday my drain fluid has become very dark red in colour. I do have the district nurse calling today so will check with her as the volume has gone up slightly as well. It has been a bit up and down anyway. I am having a bit of a panic as I really don’t want to have to go back in to hospital and worrying that there’s something wrong. Anybody else had similar? Thanks Helen x
Posts.Title: Advice re drain fluid has become dark red last 36 hours

Posts.Content: Nurse been said it was fine and not to worry! I haven’t got a temp so she wasn’t concerned. I’ll pop to hospital on Monday if I’m still worried. Thanks Helen x
Posts.Title: Advice re drain fluid has become dark red last 36 hours

Posts.Content: Hi Tracey I had mx with immediate implant 4 months ago, a Diep wasn’t an option for me as I’ve had previous abdominal surgery. As you’re having  both you will be symmetrical which I am definitely not only having had the one. It does look really good and I asked to keep my nipple which my surgeon agreed to providing she biopsied it and it was clear. My only issue is that it’s smaller than my healthy breast and I have to be honest it feels weird,  difficult to explain the feeling - sort of numb but sensitive to touch as well. I don’t like looking at myself but that’s due to them looking so different not because my new boob looks awful because it doesn’t. It is very firm feeling and doesn’t move, so you would end up with a lovely matching  pair of perky boobs. i was told to wait 6 months before I decided to have any further surgery as it takes that long for the implant to settle. I do think I will go and see a plastic surgeon to see about matching mine up better as not being symmetrical does upset me but that’s my personal opinion. I healed quickly after the op, the worst part is the drain but as soon as that comes out you’re up and running. I used a silicone gel on my scar too which smoothed it down and faded it quite quickly. Hope that helps a bit. Helen x ps I had high grade DCIS and I didn’t need any further treatment after the mx either
Posts.Title: Advice on reconstructive surgery and reduction of good breast

Posts.Content: I was 49 and  in the same position as you earlier this year and was devastated at the thought of a mastectomy but they said it would be performed with an immediate implant at the same time. It looks good, ( I asked to keep my nipple), it’s not the same same as my “good” boob and is definitely smaller so I  sometimes wear an insert in my bra to even things up - depending on what I’m wearing. I recovered quickly and don’t really have any lasting effects from the surgery. I would like to have a bigger implant I think but will see how I get on after my first check up. Good luck with your operation xx
Posts.Title: Reconstruction or not?

Posts.Content: Hi I had a right sided mastectomy 5 weeks ago with immediate reconstruction using an implant. Cosmetically it’s looking good at the moment, slightly smaller than my other one but not enough to make a difference in a bra. Was given the option on day of surgery of having the implant that you can adjust but I’d already had a lumpectomy, a SNB plus a further excision so I wanted it all over and done with. Wasn’t particularly happy that they gave me a different option on the actual day of surgery and it was the first time that it had been mentioned - decided going with original plan was best option for me. All the best for your surgery. Helen x
Posts.Title: Mastectomy tomorrow, trying to research reconstruction

Posts.Content: I used a silicone gel on my mastectomy scar once it had healed - called Scarsil, bought it from Amazon. I found it really good and my scar is now really smooth 4 months down the line and it was lumpy to start with. its early days so please don’t stress as it does get easier as time goes on. helen x
Posts.Title: Mastectomy discomfort and Scars

Posts.Content: Hi JayJ I was diagnosed with DCIS just over a 12 month ago. Had 2 lymph nodes removed and a lumpectomy, not enough clear margins so a further excision a month later. Still not enough of a clear margin so was advised to have a single mastectomy with immediate reconstruction using an implant. Only stayed in hospital overnight, did have the drain in for 2 weeks which was the worst thing to deal with. Pain wasn’t too bad after a couple of days only took paracetamol and ibuprofen. Was advised not to drive for 6 weeks which was quite frustrating because once my drain was out I felt great and wanted to get out and about.  I didn’t need any radiotherapy nor chemotherapy and was back doing most things after a few weeks. You will need to take things easy especially using the arm the side of the mastectomy but do all the stretches and exercises that they recommend. Like the others have said write a list of questions and take them with you, that’s what I did. All the best for your surgery and a speedy recovery. helen x
Posts.Title: I am new here, newly diagnosed with DCIS....

Posts.Content: Hi Had my mastectomy end of March and did have immediate reconstruction but it has left me with completely different size boobs! My new one is a lot smaller than the other one! I’ve put off trying on any strapless bras yet as having enough problems with normal ones.  We’re going away on holiday next week and I know i’ll want to wear one so I’ve just ordered some sew in bra cups that are an oval shape so will hopefully sit ok in a strapless bra - I shall let you know when they arrive and I’ve tried them. Helen x
Posts.Title: Wearing a strapless bra after mastectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Sorry I can’t answer your question but I’m likely to be in the same position as you. Had my mx 4 weeks ago tomorrow and kept my nipple with the proviso that it would be biopsied and then removed at a later date if need be. I have an appointment at the hospital tomorrow and assumed I’d get my results then. I had high grade DCIS and went through 2 excisions and a SNB prior to the mx. So I was hoping that I’d get away without any further treatment. It seems like there is no guarantee of that being the case then. Like you I’m just getting used to my new boob and am pleased with how it looks, I really don’t want to have to go through any more at this stage. I was diagnosed at the beginning of January after finding a lump back in October.  Maybe I won’t have full results back tomorrow.  They did say that by having the mx I would avoid radiotherapy, did they tell you this too? Helen x
Posts.Title: Nipple removal

Posts.Content: Hi Andy Feeling a bit anxious this morning, like you I’ve learnt that things never go according to plan. My results weren’t back 2 weeks ago when I had my drain removed.  I’ve asked a few times about medication but consultant has said it won’t be necessary so we’ll wait and see. She has said she’ll remove my nipple under local if it needs to go - can’t say I’m looking forward to that  All the best for the rest of your treatment, take care  Helen x
Posts.Title: Nipple removal

Posts.Content: Hi Andy It was good news, no further treatment and I get to keep my nipple (unless it drops off due to the previous surgeries prior to the mx) - consultant did say it was a good colour so fingers crossed. So I still have a relatively matching pair. All the best to you  Helen xx
Posts.Title: Nipple removal

Posts.Content: Just wanted to add that I would definitely try a second excision, I had 2 before they even mentioned a mastectomy to me. As Jo said, if you can keep your breast then It’s worth a try. I wish I’d been able to keep mine, my reconstructed breast looks quite good but it feels weird even a year further down the line x
